fr:mainmatter.html:p: Rijke defines an identity system on an element a:A to consist of a family of types \mathcal {I} over A equipped with the following data:

html:ol.html:li: for each family P over \mathcal {I}, a dependent function J_{\mathcal {I}}P : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (x:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (x:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (x:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (x:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {I}x\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {I}x\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {I}x\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {I}x\right )\mathclose {}}}}P{\mathopen {}\left (x,q\right )\mathclose {}} and a dependent function \beta _{\mathcal {I}}P : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{J_{\mathcal {I}}P\,p\,a\,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}} =_{P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}} {p}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {I} be an identity system on an element a:A and let B be a family of types over A. A dependent identity system over \mathcal {I} on an element b:Ba in the family B consists of a family of types \mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (x,q\right )\mathclose {}} over Bx for each x:A,q:\mathcal {I}x such that \mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{I}\right )\mathclose {}} is equipped with the structure of an identity system on b : Ba. In particular, we have:

html:ol.html:li: for each family P over \mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{I}\right )\mathclose {}}, a dependent function J_{\mathcal {J}}P : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (y:Ba\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (y:Ba\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (y:Ba\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (y:Ba\right )\mathclose {}}}}\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{P{\mathopen {}\left (y,q\right )\mathclose {}}} and a dependent function \beta _{\mathcal {J}}P:\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}} {J_{\mathcal {J}}p\,b\,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}} =_{P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}} {p}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Introduction to homotopy type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{rijke-2022, title={Introduction to Homotopy Type Theory}, author={Rijke, Egbert}, year={2022}, eprint={2212.11082}, archivePrefix={arXiv}, primaryClass={math.LO}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This is an introductory textbook to univalent mathematics and homotopy type theory, a mathematical foundation that takes advantage of the structural nature of mathematical definitions and constructions. It is common in mathematical practice to consider equivalent objects to be the same, for example, to identify isomorphic groups. In set theory it is not possible to make this common practice formal. For example, there are as many distinct trivial groups in set theory as there are distinct singleton sets. Type theory, on the other hand, takes a more structural approach to the foundations of mathematics that accommodates the univalence axiom. This, however, requires us to rethink what it means for two objects to be equal. This textbook introduces the reader to Martin-Löf’s dependent type theory, to the central concepts of univalent mathematics, and shows the reader how to do mathematics from a univalent point of view. Over 200 exercises are included to train the reader in type theoretic reasoning. The book is entirely self-contained, and in particular no prior familiarity with type theory or homotopy theory is assumed.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An event structure is defined to be triple {\mathopen {}\left (E,\mathsf {Con}_{E}, \leq _E\right )\mathclose {}} where E is a partial order of events partially ordered by the causal dependency relation \leq _E, and \mathsf {Con}_{E}\subseteq \mathcal {P}_{\mathit {fin}}{\mathopen {}\left (E\right )\mathclose {}} specifies when a finite subset of E is consistent, satisfying the following laws:

html:ol.html:li: every downset of E is finite;
any subset of a consistent subset is consistent;
for any consistent subset x\in \mathsf {Con}_{E} and e\leq e' with e'\in x, we have x\cup {\mathopen {}\left \{e\right \}\mathclose {}}\in \mathsf {Con}_{E}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The definition of event structure only speaks of finite consistent subsets; these are extended to arbitrary subsets as follows.

fr:title.text: Consistent subsets of an event structure

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Consistent subsets of an event structure

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A subset x\subseteq E of an event structure is said to be consistent when any finite subset of x lies in \mathsf {Con}_{E}.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A configuration of an event structure E is defined to be a consistent, downward-closed subset of E. We will write \mathcal {C}_{E} for the set of all configurations of E and \mathcal {C}_{E}^{\mathit {fin}} for the set of finite configurations of E.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A rigid morphism of event structures {E}\xrightarrow {{f}}{E'} is a monotone function on events that preserves finite configurations and is locally injective in the sense that for any finite configuration x\in \mathcal {C}_{E}^{\mathit {fin}} and events e_1,e_2\in x such that fe_1 = fe_2, we have e_1=e_2.

I have not checked whether the appropriate structure identity principle holds for the (pre)category of event structures and rigid morphisms. If it does not hold, this would suggest that a new univalent definition of event structure is needed.
